I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  The Government of the Maldives has requested support from the Asian Development 
Bank (ADB) to develop and install a revenue administration management information system 
(RAMIS) and to conduct a study on revenue policies and related regulatory frameworks. A 
consultation mission in August 2010 and fact-finding missions in October 2010 and July 2011 
formulated the goals and strategies of the proposed technical assistance (TA) and designed its 
corresponding activities. Extensive discussion with the government resulted in agreement on 
the  purpose  and  outputs  of  the  TA  and  its  methodology,  key  activities,  implementation 
arrangements, design and monitoring framework (Appendix 1), cost estimates (Appendix 2), 
and terms of reference for consultants (Appendix 3).1 
 
2.  The TA supports the government’s priorities as outlined in its Strategic Action Plan 
2009–2013, which identified the importance of implementing a four-pronged strategy to expand 
the  country’s  fiscal  space  to  effectively  meet  its  varied  challenges.  The  TA  will  increase 
government revenue by improving tax compliance and enhancing the efficiency of the tax 
administration.  ADB  mission  findings  reveal  that  national  income  sources  have  not  been 
adequately and efficiently tapped. The Maldives Inland Revenue Department (MIRA) urgently 
needs support to strengthen revenue administration, with the goal of augmenting government 
revenue  in  the  face  of  continued  budget  deficits  and  debt-servicing  requirements.  Greater 
revenue mobilization will pave the way for expanding and improving service delivery across the 
economy. 
 
3.  The TA is in line with ADB’s country partnership strategy (CPS) for the Maldives, 2007–
2011, recognizing that high levels of post-tsunami spending were warranted.2 However, the 
CPS warns that “the continuous increase in public consumption outlays and the widening fiscal 
deficit have become worrying.” 3 Given the country’s narrow tax base, small domestic financial 
market, and rising public debt, the pressure on the government to tackle the deficit is mounting. 
Although the TA was not included in the CPS, the government has asked ADB to provide it. 
ADB Management has approved the concept paper for the TA. 
 
4.  This TA supports ADB’s development strategy as described in the Maldives CPS, to 
“strengthen economic and financial management in areas such as tax administration.”4 ADB is 
currently assisting the government through the Economic Recovery Program (ERP) loan, which 
is part of a broad emergency program supported by international financial institutions, including 
an International Monetary Fund (IMF) standby arrangement.5 This TA builds on the work of the 
tax component of the ERP TA grant. The ERP TA grant sought to strengthen the administration 
of taxes and provide capacity development to improve reform strategies, assist in organizational 
restructuring, and develop operations manuals for MIRA. The ERP TA grant conducted surveys, 
workshops, and public awareness campaigns on tax compliance. It also reviewed and assessed 
automation needs at MIRA, and provided recommendations on implementation of IT tools.

2     
II.  ISSUES 
5.  The government’s fiscal situation is currently under stress. Government expenditures 
have risen over the past 5 years while revenues have fallen. According to the budget estimates 
for 2011, government expenditure as a percentage of the gross domestic product (GDP) stood 
at 45%, compared with 40% in 2010; meanwhile, government revenue as a percentage of GDP 
in 2011 is expected to amount to 33%, compared with 37% in 2006. As a result of increasing 
fiscal deficits, government debt increased to 91.7% in 2011.6 Fiscal and tax reforms are urgently 
needed to make public financing sustainable and avoid adverse debt dynamics. 
 
6.  To address a looming budgetary crisis, the government has agreed to fiscal and tax 
reforms.  On  the  expenditure  side,  under  an  IMF  program,  the  government  pledged  to 
permanently  reduce  government  expenditures  by  about  10%  of  GDP  in  2010  and  for  the 
following 2 years. The targeted areas of expenditure containment are reductions in civil service 
salaries and allowances, staff redundancies, electricity subsidies, and capital expenditures, and 
elimination of non-priority current expenditures. On the revenue side, the government, with 
support from ADB, is introducing new taxes and other revenue-enhancing measures, adding up 
to almost 10% of GDP in 2011 and 20% in 2012 (footnote 5). With ADB’s policy reform advice, 
the government introduced the business profit tax (BPT) and the Tourism Goods and Services 
Tax (TGST) in December 2010, and also increased the airport tax.7 The Goods and Services 
Tax (GST) Act took effect in October 2011, and personal and corporate income taxes were also 
introduced and will take effect in January 2012.8 
 
7.  The impending introduction of these new taxes by a government that has little previous 
experience in tax collection poses considerable implementation risks. There are organizational, 
managerial, and technical gaps in the newly established MIRA. ADB seeks to fill this major gap 
through this TA. By helping the government manage the installation and operation of a RAMIS, 
the  TA  will  help  equip  it  with  modern  tools  to  improve  revenue  collection  and  foster  tax 
compliance. Successfully implemented, the TA will help the government pursue a more viable 
expenditure  pattern  with  a  modern  tax  system.  The  experience  of  other  developed  and 
developing countries in utilizing e-governance to drive revenue collection reforms suggests that 
an integrated revenue administration system could have significant effects. The infusion of 
information and communication technology (ICT) in tax administration would reduce human 
errors, increase efficiency, and enhance transparency in revenue collection. Moreover, it could 
create  a  comprehensive  database  for  analysis  that  could  reduce  under  assessment  and 
improve the collection rate. Compared to other South Asian countries, the Maldives is well 
poised for this type of e-governance innovation as it has the highest internet penetration in 
South Asia, measured in terms of the percentage of internet users in the population.9 Effectively 
established, this RAMIS would produce lasting advances in fiscal reforms in the Maldives. 
                                                 
6   An increase to 91.7% in 2011 is based on 2010 IMF Article IV released in September 2011 (see Table 1, page 24). 
7  ADB, the IMF, and other international organizations have agreed on the need for a comprehensive fiscal and tax 
reform program to meet the challenges of the budgetary crisis facing the Maldives. 
8  By the end of 2011, Rf873 million and Rf146 million are to be collected as TGST and GST, respectively (a total of 
Rf1 billion).   
9  The percentage of internet usage in the Maldives is 27.2% (as of July 2011), while the percentages in other South

(8.3%). Internet World Stats: Usage and Population Statistics. http://www.internetworldstats.com. Given that most 
of the tax base is centered in Malē, which has a substantially higher internet penetration, the automated web-based 
system is expected to lead to an increase in tax collection.

3 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
8.  The impact will be enhanced fiscal space to implement the government’s Strategic 
Action Plan.10 The impact will be measured by an increase in the ratio of tax revenue to GDP. 
The outcome will be greater tax compliance and efficient tax administration. The outcome will be 
measured by (i) the higher number of registered tax filers; (ii) a reduction in the time required for 
tax  filing  management,  including appeal  and  compensation;  and  (iii)  the  lower  cost  of  tax 
collection. 
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
9.  To achieve the impact and outcome, the TA will (i) develop and install a web-based 
automated  RAMIS;  (ii)  deliver  training  programs  for  tax  officials  and  a  public  awareness 
program  for  taxpayers;  and  (iii)  conduct  a  study  on  revenue  policies  and  the  regulatory 
framework for expanding the revenue base and streamlining revenue administration.11 This TA 
provides  consultants  to  guide  the  implementation  partner  (SAP  Singapore)  in  tailoring, 
installation, and operationalization of the SAP software module in line with the government’s 
requirements. The government contracted with the implementation partner earlier in 2011 under 
its own budget, and will finance the procurement of equipment and facilities.12 
 
10.  Output 1: Establishment and activation of revenue administration management 
information system. Detailed features of output 1 will include (i) simplified taxpayer registration 
that will provide unique tax identification numbers, and issuance of certificates; (ii) improved 
collection  management  through  billing  and  payment  processing,  delinquency  monitoring 
(including nonpayment risk rating, identification of defaulters, and payment monitoring); (iii) high 
taxpayer  compliance  through  online  and  self  services  for  filing  returns  and  documents  to 
achieve compliance, assessment, and audit; and appeals to address taxpayer grievances; (iv) 
strengthened  tax  administration  using  performance  analysis,  revenue  forecasting,  notices, 
accounting, and document management; (v) facilitated refund processing and compensation, 
including prefiling notice service, inputs processing, error validation, and tax-due determination; 
(vi) creation of a taxpayer database with tax identification numbers as a prerequisite for the 
implementation  of  an  e-filing  system;  and  (vii)  online  data  exchange  between  MIRA,  the 
Department of Customs, and the Ministry of Finance and Treasury (MOFT); and e-tax filing, with 
a provision for inclusion of digital signatures in future scaled-up operations.  
 
11.  Output  2:  Enhanced  training  programs  on  the  revenue  administration 
management information system and public awareness program. The implementation of 
RAMIS is expected to lead to a more accountable system for increasing revenue collection by (i) 
enabling access to timely and accurate information, (ii) tracking collection, and (iii) enabling 
                                                 
10 Fiscal space refers to room in a government’s budget that allows it to provide resources for a desired purpose 
without jeopardizing the sustainability of its financial position or the stability of the economy. 
11 RAMIS will capture collection management as well as data on collection of personal income tax (PIT), corporate 
profit tax (CPT), business profit tax (BPT), and sales tax. Nontax revenue and customs duty will not be included; 
however, to give a complete picture of total revenue collected at any point and because of the substantial size of 
the customs duty, RAMIS will provide details of the collection of customs duty and nontax revenue. 
12 The government wanted a commercial off-the-shelf (COTS) approach, instead of customization approach, for 
developing RAMIS. Leading enterprises in the market were invited. A competitive process for procurement 
selection was undertaken by the Government which led to the contract award to SAP in July 2011. Due to the 
introduction of new taxes (GST, CPT, PIT, etc.), the implementation was delayed and has been initiated in 
December 2011.

4     
MIRA  to  reach  out  to  taxpayers  more  efficiently  and  effectively.  The  TA  will  review  the 
sustainability of RAMIS once it is installed and operationalized. Training will be provided to 
government officials on the technical aspects of RAMIS, as well as to enhance their capacity for 
change management and to increase staff knowledge on rolling out new taxes through the 
introduction of ICT–enabled tools. Subsequently, an awareness program will be conducted to 
increase  public  understanding  of  RAMIS  and  of  how  higher  revenue  resulting  from  its 
implementation enables the government to address social and economic priorities.13  
 
12.  Output 3: Newly developed revenue policies and regulatory framework. The TA will 
also  be  used  to  (i)  broaden  the revenue  base,  improve  revenue  compliance, and  explore 
additional tax and nontax revenue sources in the future; (ii) review relevant legal and regulatory 
frameworks for introducing new tax and nontax revenues; (iii) improve the efficiency of revenue 
collection through a streamlined administration process; and (iv) increase accountability and 
transparency  in  internal  governance  systems  by  reducing  human  intervention  in  revenue 
administration. 
 
13.  In terms of impact, the TA assumes that the government will remain committed to tax 
reforms during TA implementation. Changes in the leadership of key government agencies 
could reduce support for TA activities. At the outcome level, the TA assumes that the selected 
government officials will effectively manage the tax filing system that will be developed with ADB 
support and that acceptance of the new system will be widespread. The risk at this level 
includes delayed implementation of RAMIS because of resistance from tax officials and a lack of 
acceptance among stakeholders. To mitigate these risks, the TA includes training of officials 
and public awareness programs during implementation.  
 
14.  In terms of outputs, the TA assumes that the government’s demand for improving their 
tax management skills will be sufficient and that they will be able to attend training programs. 
Another assumption is that the system will capture actual functional and technical requirements 
in MIRA’s suggested solution.14 The main risks at this level are that the government officers may 
not have sufficient capacity to understand the application training. To mitigate these risks, the 
implementation  arrangements  will  guide  the  tax  audit  and  project  management  expert  in 
conducting relevant training.  
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
15.  The  government  has  asked  ADB  to  finance  $500,000  equivalent.  The  TA  will  be 
financed  on  a  grant  basis  by  ADB’s  Technical  Assistance  Special  Fund  (TASF-IV).  The 
government will provide support in the form of counterpart staff, office accommodation and 
supplies,  secretarial  assistance,  domestic  transportation,  and  communications  facilities. 
Detailed cost estimates and the financing plan are in Appendix 2.  
                                                 
13 The consultants will develop the public awareness campaign in consultation with MIRA to ensure that taxpayers 
sufficiently understand and use the ICT system.  
14 The government contracted with SAP as the implementation partner to design and install RAMIS. However, given 
the highly technical nature of this project and the complexity involved in its implementation, there is concern about 
MIRA’s insufficient technical capacity. This TA can result in bridging the gap of technical knowledge on tax audit, 
project management capacity, tax information technology, and the government’s tax policy and administration 
capacity.

5 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
16.  MOFT will be the executing agency and will liaise with ADB on TA administration matters 
in general.15 MOFT will chair a project steering committee that will include officials from MIRA 
and the Department of Customs. MIRA will be the implementing agency and will establish a 
project management unit (PMU) and appoint a project director as the focal point and principal 
liaison with ADB. MIRA will deploy a core PMU team to ensure smooth implementation of 
RAMIS, and the PMU team will comprise system analysts, programmers, and revenue business 
engineers.  
 
17.  Three international consultants will be recruited to assist the PMU in managing the 
overall RAMIS implementation. These consultants will be recruited using individual selection 
methods, in line with ADB’s Guidelines on the Use of Consultants (2010, as amended from time 
to  time).  Disbursements  will  be  made  in  accordance  with  ADB’s  Technical  Assistance 
Disbursement Handbook (2010, as amended from time to time). All procurements will be carried 
out in accordance with ADB’s Procurement Guidelines (2010, as amended from time to time). 
To ensure efficient risk management, proper quality control, and review of all the deliverables of 
the selected implementation partner for adequate and timely implementation, the TA will require 
the services of a tax audit and project management expert (international, 10 person-months); 
and a tax ICT expert (international, 5 person-months). A tax policy and administration expert 
(international,  5  person-months)  will  be  also  recruited  to  support  the continued  tax  reform 
initiative. A workshop will be held and a booklet on best practices and lessons learned in the TA 
will be published. The government will fund entirely the procurement of equipment and facilities 
for  RAMIS  and  the  procurement  procedure  will  follow  the  government’s  current  rules  and 
regulations. 
 
18.  MOFT and ADB will periodically review TA implementation. The reviews will include an 
evaluation of the project’s scope, implementation arrangements, progress, and the results of 
capacity-building measures. Specifically, MOFT and ADB staff will review and provide feedback 
on progress reports from the PMU. The PMU will submit the following reports: (i) an inception 
report (to be submitted within 30 days of the project’s commencement date), (ii) biannual 
progress reports (to be submitted within 30 days after the submission of the inception report), 
and (iii) a final report (to be submitted before project completion). A draft final report will be 
circulated 30 days prior to completion to secure comments and feedback from the government 
and ADB. A midterm review mission will be conducted at the midpoint of TA implementation. A 
final review mission will be made before completion of the TA. The TA will be implemented for 
26 months, from 1 February 2012 to 31 March 2014.  
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
19.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $500,000 on a grant basis to 
the  Government  of  the  Maldives  for  Developing  the  Revenue  Administration  Management 
Information System, and hereby reports this action to the Board. 
                                                 
15 A financial management assessment of the executing and implementing agencies was done during the loan 
processing for the Private Sector Development Project in 2008. ADB. 2008. Technical Assistance Loan to the 
Republic of the Maldives for Private Sector Development Project. Manila (Loan 2427-MLD).

(i)  Project preparation and implementation support. At the outset of the project, 
the  implementation  partner  will  prepare  various  plans  to  synchronize  all  the 
activities and to ensure that the project is completed on time. PMU consultants 
will  review  and  finalize  those  plans  in  consultation  with  the  core  team. 
Throughout the project’s implementation, the PMU will support MIRA to work 
effectively with the implementation partner to set up a customized web-based 
RAMIS. 
 
(ii)  Risk management. Risk management support will enable MIRA to identify and 
mitigate project risks on a continuous basis. 
  
(iii)  Procurement management. Procurement management will review the hardware, 
network, and other infrastructure requirement documentation and bills of material 
prepared by the implementation partner and will assist MIRA in the selection of 
an information technology (IT) infrastructure vendor. 
 
(iv)  Change  management  and  training.  Change  management  and  training 
initiatives for officials of MIRA and the Department of Customs will lead to easy 
acceptance  and  adaptation  to  a  changed  environment  post–RAMIS 
implementation. Consultants will also conduct a public-awareness survey for the 
tax-paying public. 
 
(v)  Analysis for tax base enhancement. This will help the Ministry of Finance and 
Treasury (MOFT) expand a potential tax base through policy, regulatory, and IT-
enabled reforms.

12  Appendix 3 
 
(xxi)  prepare a report capturing findings and recommendations to be presented during 
the workshop.  
 
4.  Tax information and communication technology expert (1 international, 5 person-
months). The tax ICT expert will support MIRA in the implementation of a tax and revenue 
management system (TRMS). The expert will work closely with MIRA’s commissioner general of 
taxation, MIRA staff, and the implementation partner. The expert should have at least 5 years of 
relevant experience as well as effective verbal and written communication skills. The tax ICT 
expert will: 
 
(i)  ensure that the system provider is implementing the necessary steps for: (a) 
customizing  TRMS,  Protective  Security  Coordination  Division  (PSCD),  and 
related software, and migrating from legacy tax systems; (b) customizing the 
software for integration into reporting to the Public Accounting System (PAS); 
and integration to banking institutions; 
(ii)  assist MIRA in any other aspect related to the monitoring of the contract with the 
implementation partner; 
(iii)  assist MIRA in setting up and updating an internal project plan that will include 
provider tasks, MIRA internal tasks, and other external stakeholders (MOFT, the 
Maldives Monetary Authority, and the National Centre for Information Technology, 
Banks); 
(iv)  provide assistance for MIRA’s internal team customization of the system that will 
operate after the “Go-Live,” and include in the TRMS the management of the 
other existing taxes and fees (including vehicles and properties); 
(v)  provide assistance to MIRA’s staff for the “Go-Live,” after the departure of system 
provider staff, and evaluate the situation and needs for a smooth transfer of 
operations on the new TRMS; 
(vi)  assist MIRA’s IT section with setting up an adequate plan for ongoing support 
and development of the TRMS solution after the departure of system provider 
staff; 
(vii)  help  MIRA’s  staff  prepare  the  implementation  of  customs  relationship 
management; 
(viii)  conduct a software and network security audit and prepare a plan to mitigate any 
vulnerability identified;  
(ix)  identify MIRA ICT training needs and prepare a staff development strategy for 
the next 3 years. 
(x)  conduct training and public awareness programs in consultation with MIRA; and 
(xi)  prepare a report capturing findings and recommendations to be presented during 
the workshop.  
  
5.  Tax  policy  and  administration  expert (1 international, 5 person-months).  The tax 
policy  and  administration  expert  will  support  MIRA  in  developing  a  new  tax  policy  and 
streamlined procedure, and with administration of the tax laws and regulations of the Maldives. 
The  expert  will  work  closely  with  MOFT  and  MIRA,  and  advise  MIRA  on  all  structural, 
organizational, and technical issues. The expert should have at least 10 years of relevant 
experience as well as effective verbal and written communication skills. The tax policy and 
administration expert will:

Appendix 3  13 
1.  Development of tax policy and a regulatory framework 
 
(i)  conduct a review of current tax and nontax revenue, and recommend new 
sources of revenue; 
(ii)  conduct a review of the existing legal and regulatory framework relating to 
the  revenue  system  and  recommend  a  streamlined  approach  for  the 
revenue administration; 
(iii)  study current rules and regulations concerning tax administration and 
suggest  necessary  amendments  and  modifications  if  new  taxes  are 
introduced;  
(iv)  develop  a  road  map  for  MIRA,  with  a  detailed  plan  to  enhance  the 
revenue  system  generally  and  revenue-enhancing  strategies  and 
procedures for the government; 
(v)  conduct a thorough analysis of current taxes and suggest possible new 
taxes, in line with the best practices, to increase revenue. 
(vi)  conduct  training  and  public  awareness  programs  in  consultation  with 
MIRA; and 
(vii)  prepare a report capturing findings and recommendations to be presented 
during the workshop. 
 
2.  Implementation of the goods and services tax 
 
(i)  provide support to ensure that (a) all potential taxpayers have registered; 
(b) the initial returns and payments are processed successfully; (c) all 
non-filers and/or payers, late filers and/or payers, and under-payers have 
been identified and processed; and (d) taxpayer services are provided for 
this  new  tax,  with  taxpayer  enquiries  answered  quickly,  regulations 
adapted  accordingly,  and  a  public  awareness  program  implemented 
effectively; and 
(ii)  develop  internal  procedures  for all  GST  functions,  where  required, to 
support the administration of the GST Bill. 
 
3.  Implementation of the business profit tax (to be replaced by the corporate 
profit tax and personal income tax) 
 
(i)  review the CPT and PIT laws, regulations, and existing draft manuals, 
identifying areas of potential alternative interpretations or administrative 
difficulties and help draft regulations to clarify the laws to support its 
efficient administration; 
(ii)  develop internal procedures supporting the administration of the Business 
Profit Tax Bill, Corporate Profit Tax Bill and Personal Income Tax Bill; 
(iii)  develop public awareness campaigns about the CPT and PIT, including 
roll-out sessions with the stakeholders; 
(iv)  ensure  that  all  potential  taxpayers  are  registered  and  that  taxpayer 
services are provided for this new tax, with taxpayer enquiries answered 
quickly,  regulations  adapted  accordingly,  and  a  public  awareness 
program implemented effectively; 
(v)  work with the tax audit and project management expert to design audit 
strategies and an audit manual for the CPT, PIT, and GST, and train 
MIRA staff on implementing strategies for desk and field audits;

14  Appendix 3 
 
(vi)  prepare  workshops  and  support  training  with  dedicated  institutions  to 
enhance the skill set at MIRA; and 
(vii)  review the functional solution proposed for RAMIS, and provide advice on 
the development of an appropriate administration aspect for the CPT and 
PIT.
